flow.context: Calling Gloryann Linch — Co-Owner and Managing Partner of the Moab market for Vacation Rental Collective (BookVRC). She owns the P&L for 42+ units across Rim Village, Coyote Run, and downtown Moab in one of the highest-turnover adventure markets in the country. Before VRC she was a Project Specialist at Mountain Capital Partners running CapEx and resort development for Purgatory Resort — she understands that scaling operations requires systems, not just more people. Her bio emphasizes efficiency, consistency, and meticulous attention to detail. VRC operates as a collective where local partners own their markets under a central corporate structure — CEO is Mary Beth Miles in Durango, ops director is Levi Lloyd — so Gloryann likely has autonomy for Moab but may need corporate for bigger decisions. Strongest Sam connection: shared outdoor-adventure world — Sam skis, fishes, surfs; Gloryann came from the ski resort industry and runs properties in a national park market. Direct number: 801-513-3299.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Gloryann — I work with a few other vacation rental managers in outdoor adventure markets, and your name actually came up when I was looking into operators in Moab who came out of the resort world. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Relaxed, warm tone. Feet up on the desk. The resort reference is real — she came from Mountain Capital Partners and Purgatory Resort. Don't explain further unless she asks.

branches.label: No, I haven't heard of you
Who is this? / What's this about?

no_heard.label: THEY HAVEN'T HEARD OF YOU
no_heard.say: Ha — I guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call — I was looking into operators in the Moab market and saw you took over the VRC collection back in 2020 coming from resort development at Mountain Capital. Figured you'd get what I'm about to describe better than most.
no_heard.note: Transition naturally into the pain trigger. The Mountain Capital reference positions her as someone who 'gets it' — scaling hospitality through systems.

branches.label: I'm really busy / not a good time

yes_heard.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
yes_heard.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone like you. What'd you hear?
yes_heard.note: Genuine curiosity. Let her talk. Whatever she says, bridge to the pain trigger.

who_is_this.label: WHO IS THIS
who_is_this.say: Yeah totally fair — it's Sam Parks with RapidEye. I work with a few property management companies on their inspection workflows. Your name came up when I was looking into the Moab market. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I called? You can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit.
who_is_this.note: Don't get defensive. Be direct and ask for permission. Smile through it.

what_selling.label: WHAT ARE YOU SELLING
what_selling.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call, I'll be honest. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? And you can totally hang up on me if it's not relevant.
what_selling.note: Own the cold call. Honesty disarms. Ask for permission with a time limit.

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow, maybe morning before things get crazy?
bad_timing.note: Suggest a specific time. Get a soft commitment. Don't push. She's in Mountain Time.

branches.label: Yeah try me tomorrow / gives a time

lock_callback.label: LOCK THE CALLBACK
lock_callback.say: Perfect — I've got tomorrow morning pulled up. Would 9 AM Mountain work, or is there a better window?
lock_callback.note: Pin down an actual time. Don't leave it vague. Set a reminder the second you hang up.

callback_confirmed.label: CALLBACK CONFIRMED
callback_confirmed.say: Awesome — I'll give you a ring then. Really appreciate it, Gloryann. Talk soon.
callback_confirmed.note: Short and clean. Set a reminder immediately after hanging up. Don't oversell the callback.

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it more that you already know what we do and it's just not interesting?
permission_rejected.note: Split the objection. The 'so nobody bugs you again' line gives her a reason to answer honestly.

branches.label: I'm not interested / we're all set

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: So I was talking to another managing partner who runs about 40 units in a high-turnover adventure market — pretty similar setup to yours in Moab. She was telling me her team reviews turnover photos on every flip, but with the volume of guests coming through — especially the big groups — stuff was slipping. Scuffs on walls, missing items, that red dust buildup on baseboards the cleaner didn't catch. And the worst part was she couldn't tie the damage back to a specific guest because nobody flagged it until two or three turnovers later. She was eating thousands a month she couldn't recover.
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE HERE. Let the silence sit. Do not rush to the solution. The red dust detail is Moab-specific and will hit home. Watch for a sigh, an 'mmhmm,' or her jumping in with her own version — any of those means she's warm.

branches.label: Yeah, that sounds familiar / we deal with that
Okay... so what do you do?
We've got a pretty good handle on that
I don't really have time for this

warm_response.label: THEY FEEL THE PAIN
warm_response.say: Yeah — that's exactly what we keep hearing. So we built a tool that plugs into the inspection photos your team's already taking on turnovers and uses AI to automatically flag damage, missing items, cleaning misses — before the next guest checks in. No workflow change at all. What does your turnover process look like right now — are your cleaners taking photos on every flip?
warm_response.note: She's warm. Give the one-sentence solution then IMMEDIATELY pivot to a discovery question. Stop pitching. Let her talk.

branches.label: Yes, they take photos / describes process
We use a tool or software for that
That's interesting but this might be a corporate decision

one_sentence_solution.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION
one_sentence_solution.say: We built an AI tool that plugs into the turnover photos your team's already taking and automatically flags damage, missing items, and cleaning issues — no workflow change on your end. Would you be open to seeing what that looks like when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue?
one_sentence_solution.note: Quick and clean. Don't over-explain. The CTA is low-friction — asking for a look, not a purchase.

branches.label: We already have something for that
I don't think we have budget

explain_briefly.label: BRIEF EXPLANATION
explain_briefly.say: Yeah so — simplest way to think about it: your cleaners or inspectors take photos on turnovers, right? Those photos go into whatever system you're using. We sit on top of that and run AI analysis on every single photo — looking for damage, missing items, staging issues, cleaning problems. You get a report before the next guest arrives flagging anything that needs attention. The whole point is nobody changes what they already do.
explain_briefly.note: Keep it simple. Don't get technical. If she asks about specific PMS integration, that's a great sign — use it to book the meeting.

branches.label: That's interesting — I'd be open to seeing it
Does it work with our software?
I'd need to talk to Mary Beth or corporate about this

discovery_deep.label: DEEP DISCOVERY
discovery_deep.say: Got it. And when something does get missed — like a guest damages a wall or something walks off — how are you catching that now? Is it the next cleaner who spots it, or does someone review the photos?
discovery_deep.note: Dig for the gap between their process and reality. Most managers know things slip through. Let her admit it. Don't lead — ask and listen.

branches.label: Honestly it's inconsistent / stuff slips through
We have a pretty tight process
It depends on the property or the cleaner

discovery_tech_stack.label: DISCOVER TECH STACK
discovery_tech_stack.say: Oh interesting — what are you guys using?
discovery_tech_stack.note: Find out their PMS or ops tool. This is gold for the demo. If they mention Track, Breezeway, or similar, we likely integrate. Write it down.

branches.label: I'm not sure / our ops person handles that

tech_integration.label: TECH INTEGRATION
tech_integration.say: Oh nice — yeah we actually plug right into that. That's exactly the kind of setup where this works best because the photos are already flowing through the system. Honestly, the best thing would be for me to show you how it looks with your actual workflow. Would you be open to a 15-minute walkthrough sometime this week?
tech_integration.note: If they name their PMS, match energy — 'oh nice' keeps it casual. Use the integration as the bridge to book the meeting.

branches.label: This week's crazy — maybe next week
I'd need to loop in our ops team or corporate

pitch_meeting_warm.label: PITCH THE MEETING — WARM
pitch_meeting_warm.say: Yeah that's exactly what we hear from everyone. And honestly the best way to see if this is even relevant is for me to show you what it actually catches. It's like a 15-minute walkthrough — I can show you real examples from properties similar to yours. Would you be open to that sometime this week or next?
pitch_meeting_warm.note: She's admitted the gap. Don't keep digging — offer the meeting. Be specific about the time ask.

branches.label: I need to check with Mary Beth or corporate first
I don't have budget right now

acknowledge_and_pitch.label: ACKNOWLEDGE TIGHT PROCESS
acknowledge_and_pitch.say: That's awesome — honestly most people I talk to don't have that dialed in. Out of curiosity though — is the review manual, like someone's eyeballing every photo? Or is there any automation on the back end?
acknowledge_and_pitch.note: Compliment the process, then probe for the manual gap. Almost everyone is doing manual review even if they feel good about it.

branches.label: It's mostly manual / someone reviews them
We have automation or software for it

manual_gap_pitch.label: MANUAL GAP PITCH
manual_gap_pitch.say: Yeah that makes sense. And that works — until the volume spikes in spring and your reviewers are looking at hundreds of photos a day. That's exactly where we come in — we automate that review so your team catches everything without the bottleneck. Would you be open to a quick look at how it works?
manual_gap_pitch.note: Connect to Moab seasonality. Spring shoulder season is the highest-pressure time. She'll feel this.

branches.label: I'm not sure we need it

objection_not_interested.label: NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: Totally get it. I should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that inspections aren't a priority right now, or is it more that you've already got something working and switching would be a headache?
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first. Don't argue. Split the objection to find the real reason.

branches.label: It's not a priority right now
We already have something that works
I just don't want to deal with it
Really not for us — please don't call

objection_no_budget.label: NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone buy something new. Just so I'm not wasting your time — is it that budget for this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything new you try to bring in goes through a whole approval process with corporate?
objection_no_budget.note: Agree first. Split the objection. If it's approval, you might need Mary Beth. If it's timing, sell the test drive.

branches.label: Budget is locked / we can't spend right now
Anything new goes through corporate or Mary Beth
It's just not a priority spend

objection_have_process.label: ALREADY HAVE SOMETHING
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with 40-plus units you'd have to have something in place. Is it that you're fully covered and happy with how it's working, or is it more that ripping anything out and replacing it would just be a pain?
objection_have_process.note: Agree first. Split. If happy, offer comparison value. If switching is the pain, emphasize we layer on top — no rip and replace.

branches.label: We're happy with what we have

offer_comparison.label: OFFER COMPARISON
offer_comparison.say: Totally respect that. If nothing else — would you be open to seeing what other managers in adventure markets are doing with their turnover photos right now? Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends. No pressure at all.
offer_comparison.note: This is the 'offer of value' play. The meeting is worth her time even if she never buys.

no_rip_replace.label: NO RIP AND REPLACE
no_rip_replace.say: Oh — totally. We actually don't replace anything. We layer on top of whatever you're already using. Your team keeps doing exactly what they do now — we just analyze the photos that are already flowing through your system. That's actually why I wanted to show you — it's a 15-minute look and you'd know right away if it fits. Would you be open to that?
no_rip_replace.note: This is a common misconception. Clarify fast — RapidEye is additive, not a replacement. This often converts the objection immediately.

branches.label: Oh okay — sure, I'd look at it
I'd still need to talk to corporate

corporate_decision.label: CORPORATE DECISION
corporate_decision.say: Oh yeah — with the collective model I figured there might be a corporate piece to this. Would it make sense for me to connect with Mary Beth directly, or would you rather see it first and then bring it up if it's relevant for Moab?
corporate_decision.note: Drop Mary Beth's name casually — shows you understand their structure. Let Gloryann decide the path. Either way you win: direct intro to the CEO, or Gloryann becomes your internal champion for Moab.

branches.label: You should probably talk to Mary Beth
Let me see it first, then I'll decide
I can make this call for Moab myself
I'd want to loop in Levi too

referral_marybeth.label: REFERRAL TO MARY BETH
referral_marybeth.say: That'd be super helpful. Would you be open to making an intro, or would it be better if I reached out to her directly and mentioned we spoke? I just want to make sure it lands the right way.
referral_marybeth.note: Let Gloryann choose the path. A warm intro is gold. If she prefers cold outreach, you still have social proof — 'I spoke with Gloryann about your Moab operations.'

branches.label: I can intro you / I'll mention it to her
Just reach out to her directly

lock_marybeth_intro.label: LOCK MARY BETH INTRO
lock_marybeth_intro.say: That's awesome — I really appreciate that. Would it be easiest if I sent you a quick email you could forward to her, or would you rather just loop us both in on a thread? Whatever's simplest for you.
lock_marybeth_intro.note: Make it as easy as possible for her. Offer to do the work. Confirm Mary Beth's contact info if you can.

branches.label: Send me something and I'll forward it
I'll just tell her to expect your call

lock_marybeth_direct.label: LOCK MARY BETH DIRECT OUTREACH
lock_marybeth_direct.say: Perfect — I'll reach out to her and mention that you and I connected. Is marybeth at bookvrc the best way to get her, or is there a better line?
lock_marybeth_direct.note: Confirm contact info. You already have marybeth@bookvrc.com but confirming shows thoroughness. Try to get a phone number if possible.

branches.label: I'm not sure — try the main number

referral_levi.label: REFERRAL TO LEVI
referral_levi.say: Oh — Levi Lloyd, right? Yeah that makes sense with his ops background. Would it work best to set something up with all of us, or should I connect with him separately first?
referral_levi.note: Dropping Levi's name shows deep research. A group meeting is ideal — harder to cancel and you get multiple stakeholders.

referral_ops.label: REFERRAL TO OPS PERSON
referral_ops.say: Totally — who on your team handles the turnover and inspection workflow day to day? If I can get a name, I'll put something tailored together so it actually lands the right way.
referral_ops.note: She might not know the tech details. Get the name of whoever runs ops — could be Levi, could be someone local in Moab.

branches.label: Gives a name / points to someone
That's probably Levi, our ops director

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: You're probably not buying anything right now, and I totally respect that. But when budget does free up — or when you're planning for next season — the people who are ready are the ones who already know what's on their list. Would you be open to just taking a look? Not for now, but so you know what's out there. If nothing else I can walk you through what other adventure-market managers are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas.
sell_test_drive.note: Long-game play. You're not asking her to buy — you're asking her to be informed. Moab's spring rush starts in March, so 'planning for next season' is a real trigger.

branches.label: Sure, that's fair / I'd take a look

defer_price.label: DEFER PRICING
defer_price.say: Totally fair question. It honestly depends on unit count and how you're set up — I don't want to throw a number out that doesn't mean anything. That's actually one of the things we'd cover in a walkthrough. Can I show you what it does first and then we can talk numbers with your actual setup in mind?
defer_price.note: Never quote price on a cold call. Pivot to the meeting. Price without context always sounds expensive.

ballpark_redirect.label: BALLPARK REDIRECT
ballpark_redirect.say: For a portfolio your size — somewhere in the 40-unit range — most of our customers are paying less per month than what one missed damage incident costs them. But I really want to show you the actual output first so the number makes sense. How does later this week look for 15 minutes?
ballpark_redirect.note: Give a value-anchored ballpark without a dollar figure. Redirect to the meeting immediately.

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next week pulled up — would Tuesday or Wednesday work better for you? I'm thinking mid-morning, maybe 10 AM Mountain.
book_meeting.note: Pick a day and time. Be specific. Don't say 'when works for you' — give two options. Send the invite WHILE on the phone if possible.

branches.label: Let me check my calendar and get back to you

pin_down_meeting.label: PIN DOWN THE MEETING
pin_down_meeting.say: Totally — tell you what, I'll shoot you an invite for Wednesday at 10 AM Mountain just to hold the spot, and if you need to move it just let me know. What's the best email — moab at bookvrc?
pin_down_meeting.note: Don't let it float. Send a calendar hold now. Confirm her email. moab@bookvrc.com is the published one but she might have a personal address.

meeting_confirmed.label: MEETING CONFIRMED
meeting_confirmed.say: Perfect — you'll get that invite in the next couple minutes. Really appreciate you taking my call, Gloryann. Looking forward to showing you what we've got.
meeting_confirmed.note: STOP SELLING. Meeting is booked. Be grateful, be brief, get off the phone. Send the invite immediately after hanging up.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair — I'll send something over. One quick question before I do — what would be most helpful to include so it's not just another generic pitch? Are you more interested in the actual inspection output, or more like how it fits into your current workflow?
send_email.note: Accept the email request, then ask ONE qualifying question. This tells you what to put in the email AND keeps the conversation going for another beat. Always include specific meeting times in the email.

branches.label: Tells you what they want to see
Just send me whatever / general info

confirm_email_close.label: CONFIRM EMAIL AND CLOSE
confirm_email_close.say: Got it — I'll send that over today. Is moab at bookvrc the best email, or is there a better one for you directly? And I'll include a couple times to connect in case you want to dig in after you see it.
confirm_email_close.note: Confirm the email address. Always include 2-3 specific meeting time options in the follow-up. Gloryann's published email is moab@bookvrc.com.

branches.label: Gives a different or personal email

email_close_final.label: EMAIL CLOSE
email_close_final.say: Perfect — keep an eye out for that today. Really appreciate your time, Gloryann. Talk soon.
email_close_final.note: Send the email within 30 minutes while the call is fresh. Personalize it — reference something she said on the call. Include 2-3 specific time options. Mention the resort development background or Moab specifics to prove it's not a template.

last_chance_pitch.label: LAST CHANCE
last_chance_pitch.say: Totally hear you — I'll be super quick. We built an AI tool that reviews the turnover photos your team already takes and automatically catches damage, missing items, and cleaning issues. No workflow change. I work with a few other managers running 40-plus units in markets like yours. Would you be open to a 15-minute look when you're not in the middle of your day?
last_chance_pitch.note: Compressed version — pain plus solution plus CTA in one breath. This is your last shot before she hangs up.

end_gracefully.label: END GRACEFULLY
end_gracefully.say: Totally understand. If anything changes, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks at RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Gloryann.
end_gracefully.note: Don't burn the bridge. Be warm and respectful. She might Google you later. Log the call and set a reminder to try again in 60-90 days — next time reference Mary Beth's Powering Travel podcast or a new case study from a similar adventure market.
